newsitem.title: POLAND: Zloty ends flat after tracking dollar losses.
newsitem.headline: Zloty ends flat after tracking dollar losses.

text.p: The Polish zloty closed nearly unchanged against the basket of currencies after spending the session cautiously adjusting to the dollar's plunge against the mark in European trade, dealers said.
The session started with players selling zlotys on expectations that the dollar's slide was a correction, but the Polish unit hit support and was left to follow world trends.

"Early dollar-buying pulled the zloty down to support at 1.80 percent from parity, but from then on the market followed international dollar movements with nothing special happening here," said Marcin Stefaniuk from BDK SA.
The zloty closed at 1.92/1.82 percent from the trading band centre against 1.91/1.86 percent on Tuesday.
Zloty was at 2.8150/80 to the dollar, up from 2.8261/76 on Tuesday and at 1.8505/25 to the mark, down from 1.8418/27.

Liquidity on the money market decreased slightly and pulled overnight deposit rates up to 19.1/19.5 percent, from 19.1/19.3 at opening, as banks did not want to let out cash before balancing end-of-month required reserve accounts.
Tomorrow/next were at 19.2/19.5 percent against opening's 19.1/19.35 percent, which may have also reflected the impact of the second day of monthly tax payment outflows.

"Banks had less money on Wednesday, but most probably set cash aside for taxes so the decreased liquidity was likely to be connected to the monthly reserve, which ends in a few days," said Renata Krajewska of PKO BP.
There were only small deals on the secondary T-bill market, focused on the longest 52-week papers quoted at 19.46/19.44 percent against the average yield of 19.46 percent at Monday's primary tender.
